Recent research on trade shocks (e.g., Autor Dorn and Hansen, 2013) and the effects of the great recession (e.g., Yagan, 2013) shows surprising large and persistent effects of localized shocks, consistent with the idea that the elasticity of supply to local labor markets is relatively inelastic.

For example, the empirical literature on monopsony has focused on the market for nurses (e.g., Staiger, Spetz, and Phibbs, 2010) and teachers (e.g., Ransom and Sims, 2010; Falch, 2011) based on a presumption that firms have more wage setting power in these occupational labor markets. By contrast, Ashenfelter and Hannan (1986) and Black and Strahan (2001) use the product market to define their labor market of interest ÃÂ¢Ãâ¬Ãâ they study the effects of banking deregulation on the gender composition and relative wages of bank employees.
